t: Psalm 78
Lessons from Israel’s Past
A Maskil of Asaph.
My*pn people, hear my instruction; listen*ln to the words from my mouth.
I*ln will declare wise sayings; I*ln will speak mysteries from the past—
things*ln we have heard and known and*ln that our ancestors have passed down to us.
We*ln will not hide them from their children, but*ln will tell a future generation the*ln praiseworthy acts of the Lord,*s his*ln might, and the wondrous works he*ln has performed.
He*ln established a testimony in Jacob and*ln set up a law in Israel, which*ln he commanded our ancestors to*ln teach to their children
so*ln that a future generation — children*ln yet to be born - might know. They*ln were to rise and tell their children
so*ln that they might put their confidence in God and*ln not forget God’s works, but*ln keep his commands.
Then*ln they would not be like their ancestors, a*ln stubborn and rebellious generation, a*ln generation whose heart was not loyal and*ln whose spirit was not faithful to God.
The*pn Ephraimite archers turned back on*ln the day of battle.
They*ln did not keep God’s covenant and*ln refused to live by his law.
They*ln forgot what he had done, the*ln wondrous works he had shown them.
He*ln worked wonders in the sight of their ancestors in*ln the land of Egypt, the territory of Zoan.
He*ln split the sea and brought them across; the*ln water stood firm like a wall.
He*ln led them with a cloud by day and*ln with a fiery light throughout the night.
He*ln split rocks in the wilderness and*ln gave them drink as abundant as the depths.
He*ln brought streams out of the stone and*ln made water flow down like rivers.
But*pn they continued to sin against him, rebelling*ln in the desert against the Most High.
They*ln deliberately tested God, demanding*ln the food they craved.
They*ln spoke against God, saying, “Is*ln God able to provide food in the wilderness?
Look!*ln He struck the rock and water gushed out; torrents*ln overflowed. But*ln can he also provide bread or*ln furnish meat for his people?”
Therefore,*ln the Lord*s heard and became furious; then*ln fire broke out against Jacob, and*ln anger flared up against Israel
because*ln they did not believe God or*ln rely on his salvation.
He*ln gave a command to the clouds above and*ln opened the doors of heaven.
He*ln rained manna for them to eat; he*ln gave them grain from heaven.
People*ln ate the bread of angels. He*ln sent them an abundant supply of food.
He*ln made the east wind blow in the skies and*ln drove the south wind by his might.
He*ln rained meat on them like dust, and*ln winged birds like the sand of the seas.
He*ln made them fall in the camp, all*ln around the tents.
The*ln people ate and were completely satisfied, for*ln he gave them what they craved.
Before*ln they had turned from what they craved, while*ln the food was still in their mouths,
God’s*ln anger flared up against them, and*ln he killed some of their best men. He*ln struck down Israel’s fit young men.
Despite*pn all this, they kept sinning and*ln did not believe his wondrous works.
He*ln made their days end in futility, their*ln years in sudden disaster.
When*ln he killed some of them, the*ln rest began to seek him; they*ln repented and searched for God.
They*ln remembered that God was their rock, the*ln Most High God, their Redeemer.
But*ln they deceived him with their mouths, they*ln lied to him with their tongues,
their*ln hearts were insincere toward him, and*ln they were unfaithful to his covenant.
Yet*ln he was compassionate; he*ln atoned for their iniquity and*ln did not destroy them. He*ln often turned his anger aside and*ln did not unleash all his wrath.
He*ln remembered that they were only flesh, a*ln wind that passes and does not return.
How*pn often they rebelled against him in*ln the wilderness and*ln grieved him in the desert.
They*ln constantly tested God and*ln provoked the Holy One of Israel.
They*ln did not remember his power shown on*ln the day he redeemed them from the foe,
when*ln he performed his miraculous signs in Egypt and*ln his wonders in the territory of Zoan.
He*ln turned their rivers into blood, and*ln they could not drink from their streams.
He*ln sent among them swarms of flies, which*ln fed on them, and*ln frogs, which devastated them.
He*ln gave their crops to the caterpillar and*ln the fruit of their labor to the locust.
He*ln killed their vines with hail and*ln their sycamore fig trees with a flood.
He*ln handed over their livestock to hail and*ln their cattle to lightning bolts.
He*ln sent his burning anger against them: fury,*ln indignation, and calamity — a*ln band of deadly messengers.
He*ln cleared a path for his anger. He*ln did not spare them from death but*ln delivered their lives to the plague.
He*ln struck all the firstborn in Egypt, the*ln first progeny of the tents of Ham.
He*ln led his people out like sheep and*ln guided them like a flock in the wilderness.
He*ln led them safely, and they were not afraid; but*ln the sea covered their enemies.
He*ln brought them to his holy territory, to*ln the mountain his right hand acquired.
He*ln drove out nations before them. He*ln apportioned their inheritance by lot and*ln settled the tribes of Israel in their tents.
But*pn they rebelliously tested the Most High God, for*ln they did not keep his decrees.
They*ln treacherously turned away like their ancestors; they*ln became warped like a faulty bow.
They*ln enraged him with their high places and*ln provoked his jealousy with their carved images.
God*ln heard and became furious; he*ln completely rejected Israel.
He*ln abandoned the tabernacle at Shiloh, the*ln tent where he resided among mankind.
He*ln gave up his strength to captivity and*ln his splendor to the hand of a foe.
He*ln surrendered his people to the sword because*ln he was enraged with his heritage.
Fire*ln consumed his chosen young men, and*ln his young women had no wedding songs.
His*ln priests fell by the sword, and*ln the widows could not lament.
The*pn Lord awoke as if from sleep, like*ln a warrior from the effects of wine.
He*ln beat back his foes; he*ln gave them lasting disgrace.
He*ln rejected the tent of Joseph and*ln did not choose the tribe of Ephraim.
He*ln chose instead the tribe of Judah, Mount*ln Zion, which he loved.
He*ln built his sanctuary like the heights, like*ln the earth that he established forever.
He*ln chose David his servant and*ln took him from the sheep pens;
he*ln brought him from tending ewes to*ln be shepherd over his people Jacob — over*ln Israel, his inheritance.
He*ln shepherded them with a pure heart and*ln guided them with his skillful hands.
